AUSTRALIA

Adelaide Brighton Limited (ABC AT)
- Co. CEO Brydon is planning to retire. (Newswires)

Atlas Iron (AGO AT)
- Co. sees FY non-cash impairment charge of AUD 75mln-100mln. (Newswires)

Brambles (BXB AT)
- Brambles a block trade of about 40mln shares was reported late yesterday at AUD 9.40/Shr vs. last close AUD 9.61. (Newswires)

Dulux Group (DLX AT)
- Co. H1 net AUD 79.2mln vs. Prev. AUD 72.7mln Y/Y. (Newswires)
- Co. Chairman is to retire.

Link Administration Holdings (LNK AT)
- Co. affirms FY18 revenue impact of about AUD 55mln due to possible changes in regulations. (Newswires)

Origin Energy (ORG AT)
- Co. received various binding bids for its smart power business valued around AUD 200mln. (AFR)

Santos (STO AT)
- Co. is said to receive an offer of AUD 4.98/Shr vs. last close AUD 6.32. (AFR)

Telstra (TLS AT)
- Co. CEO Penn could be on track for removal amid investor dismay and viewed to likely be replaced by NBN CEO Marrow. (The Australian)

Transurban (TCL AT)
- ACCC is reportedly concerned regarding Co. interest in WestConnex which could further strengthen its advantages. (Newswires)

Treasury Wine Estates (TWE AT)
- Co. is said to be facing over supply issues on some of its products in China. (AFR)

Broker Moves
- Crown Resorts (CWN AT) downgraded to neutral from overweight at JPMorgan.
- Macquarie Atlas (MQA AT) downgraded to equal weight from overweight at Morgan Stanley.
- Sydney Airport (SYD AT) downgraded to equal weight from overweight at Morgan Stanley.

JAPAN

Fast Retailing (9983 JT)
- Co. it to set up its 15th global Uniqlo flagship store in Manila. (Nikkei)

Fujitsu (6702 JT)
- Co. and Lenovo (992 HK) unveiled an AI device that reads facial expressions. (Nikkei)

Hitachi (6501 JT)
- Co. is said to have reached an agreement regarding UK nuclear power plant project. (Newswires)

Honda (7267 JT)
- Co. will resume sales of its flagship CR-V SUV in China. (Nikkei)

MS&AD Insurance Group (8725 JT)
- Co. may report FY17/18 net of around JPY 150bln vs. guidance of JPY 145bln. (Newswires)

Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal (5401 JT)
- Co. says it will seize on current market climate in offensive to reclaim lost ground from Chinese competitors. (Nikkei)

Sompo Holdings (8630 JT)
- Co. may report FY17/18 net of around JPY 140bln vs. guidance of JPY 152bln. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT)
- S&P raised rating to B from CCC+; outlook remains on watch positive. (Newswires)

Healthcare / Infrastructure
- Japan plans to promote exports of medical-related infrastructure to the Indian market. (Nikkei)

SOUTH KOREA

Geopolitical
- US President Trump said 'we'll have to see' if the North Korea summit is still on and will insist on the denuclearisation of North Korea, while US National Security Adviser Bolton said that the Trump-Kim summit should still happen even though North Korea is threatening to back out. (Fox News)
- South Korea is said to have no plans yet to reach North Korea through hotline. (Newswires)

Other News
- South Korea firms saw a 10% increase in earnings in Q1, with gains led by Samsung Electronics (005930 KS). (Nikkei)
- South Korea Finance Ministry maintained view that FX should be driven by markets and stated it will initially disclose FX intervention data on a half-year basis. (Newswires)

content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump stated the US has little to give to China whilst China has much to give, while he added that we have not seen China’s demands yet which should be few, while China has seen the US demands and that there has been no folding as the media would love people to believe. (Newswires)


UK

UK is to tell EU it is prepared to remain in customs union arrangement beyond 2021. (Telegraph)


EU

Italy's M5S and the League have completed the joint policy programme and passed on the document to leaders for its approval, although it is not due to be officially released until the weekend. Furthermore, the Five Star and League government contract is said not to include a Euro exit option. (Newswires)

EU CPI Final MM (Apr) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 1.0%). (Newswires)
EU CPI Final YY (Apr) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%)


FX

Brazilian Selic Interest Rate 6.50% vs. Exp. 6.25% (Prev. 6.50%); vote was unanimous. (Newswires)

BoC’s Schembri said April's upward revision to potential output means they have more room than expected to support demand without causing inflationary pressures in the near term. Schembri added that Canada's recent deals on CETA and TPP are helping reduce trade barriers. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (11 May) -1.404M vs. Exp. -0.763M (Prev. -2.197M); production +0.19% at 10.723mln bpd. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia believes a brief oil price spike driven by speculators is not a reason for producers to increase output and also stated that oil prices at USD 79/bbl are ‘not yet’ too high, according to sources. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh stated Iran will be doing its best to maintain production and continue exports, while he also commented that oil prices at USD 60-65/bbl are 'logical' and the US wants to see high prices to boost shale production. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said 'we'll have to see' if the North Korea summit is still on and will insist on the denuclearisation of North Korea, while US National Security Adviser Bolton said that the Trump-Kim summit should still happen even though North Korea is threatening to back out. (Fox News)

Paris continues to work with Iran to expand the agreement by adding its missile programme and actions in the region to the deal whilst preserving original JCPOA, according to a French ambassador speaking to Russia. (Newswires)
 

US

Trump legal adviser Giuliani said Special Counsel Mueller told the Trump team that he will adhere to Justice Department guidance that a sitting president cannot be indicted. (CNN)

Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) said is US close to neutral rate, while he also commented that there is no yield curve inversion danger just now and that it has a nice slope. (Newswires)

Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said it is basically impossible to have a NAFTA deal by tomorrow and that NAFTA ministers are exploring the possibility of meeting again. Guajardo added that the soft deadline has some margin of flexibility and does not rule out reaching a NAFTA deal from end of May onwards. (Newswires)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro was initially said to be excluded from China talks, but then the White House later stated that Navarro will now be attending the meeting tomorrow, while separate reports stated that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, Commerce Secretary Ross and Trade Representative Lighthizer are to meet with the Chinese delegation. In other news, US Senator Hatch commented that he expects China trade tariffs to go into effect. (Newswires)

US House Ways and Means Committee Chair Brady said Chinese Vice-Premier Liu wants to increase Chinese demand for US products and that he does see problems in trade relations, although he added that Liu is said to be optimistic about trade talks. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi denounced trade unilateralism abd noted that free trade on basis of WTO rules must be kept. (Newswires)

US Industrial Production MM (Apr) 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.7%). (Newswires)
US Manufacturing Output MM (Apr) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.1%)
US Housing Starts Number (Apr) 1.287M vs. Exp. 1.310M (Prev. 1.319M, Rev. 1.336M)
US Building Permits Number (Apr) 1.352M vs. Exp. 1.350M (Prev. 1.379M, Rev. 1.377M)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures consolidated around Tuesday’s closing level until US traders got to their desks on Wednesday, content to roam in the range between 2705 and 2720 until afternoon trade, when the ES broke out, but couldn’t manage to hold ground too far above the level after a bout of political headlines from the US (Navarro). Sector specifics, utilities underperformed given the defensive nature of the sector as it was the only sector in the red at market close following a risk on tone being taken by markets, on the flipside, materials outperformed. SPX +0.39% at 2722, NDX +0.60% at ,6929 DJI +0.24% at 24700.

Treasuries ended the day pretty much unchanged, despite decent volumes and a busy day in the European fixed income complex, where Italian BTPs tumbled amid political uncertainty whilst German bunds acted as a safe haven alternative. Treasury yields were higher by less than 1bps, with the exception of the 10yr yield which was higher by just about 1bps, consolidating yesterday’s gains above the 3% level. Heading towards settlement, 2s10s widened by c.1bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 2 ticks lower at 118-17+.

US MARKET WRAP 16 May 2018: Italian BTPs slammed amid political uncertainty, NAFTA deal unlikely on Thursday, US yields print fresh cyclical highs
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY flat, Crude up
  • * REAR-VIEW: US Industrial Production, Italian politics, BoC’s Schembri, Fed's Williams, Bostic and Bullard
  • * AHEAD: CSCO earnings, BCB expected to cut 25bps (after-market), Australian labour force (overnight). On Thursday; US Initial jobless claims, Mexican Interest Rate, ECB's Constancio, Fed's Kashkari & Kaplan, and BoE's Haldane to speak

 

*ITALIAN POLITICS: On Wednesday, focus fell on political developments in the country as the 5-Star and League alliance gets closer to a Government coalition deal, that appears set to challenge EU on various fronts. The League and the M5S were looking to ask the ECB to scrape out EUR 250bln of the country’s debt, though this was later denied. Italian BTPs were sold heavily, falling over 2 points in the session as uncertainty grew over the timing of a government agreement, initially scheduled for last Sunday.  Later in the session, BTPs took a breather and moved-off lows after the League’s economics chief said the two parties have completed the joint policy programme and passed on the document to leaders for its approval; other sources reported that the contract did not to include a Euro exit option. Italy's M5S leader Di Maio said details regarding the government contract will be distributed over the weekend, and will be followed by a M5S new online referendum vote. The FTSE MIB was also the lagged its peers, ending the session down more than 2%.

*BANK OF CANADA: BoC Deputy Governor Schembri recognised that lower interest rates creates financial vulnerabilities, arguing rates were below neutral due to NAFTA uncertainty, noting that the uncertainty is having a negative impact on businesses’ investment decisions. Schembri also argued that April's upward revision to potential output means that BOC has more room than expected to support demand without causing inflationary pressures in the near term, adding that Canada's recent deals on CETA and TPP are helping reduce trade barriers.

* TRADE: US President Trump said in a tweet the US has little to give to China whilst China has much to give, noting he has not seen demands from the country. On ZTE, he said it ‘pertains to the larger trade deal’. Separately, Trump claimed 'we'll have to see' if the North Korea summit is still on and he will insist on its denuclearisation. Trump Security Adviser Bolton, during a Fox News radio interview, said the Trump-Kim summit should still happen even though North Korea is threatening to back out. House Ways and Means Chair Brady said Chinese Vice-Premier Liu wants to increase Chinese demand for US products, he does see problems in trade relations. Liu appeared optimistic about his expectations for talks this week. Elsewhere, White House Trade Adviser Navarro is said to be excluded from China talks, according to reports. Other reports suggested he will not be one of the principles.

*IRANIAN NUCLEAR DEAL: EU's Juncker said he would like to keep the Iran nuclear deal alive, noting it is important for peace, highlighting the EU is very attached to multilateral system. Iran’s oil minister mentioned that Iran will be doing its best to maintain production and continue exports

*NAFTA: Mexico’s economy minister Guajardo said it was impossible to reach an agreement on NAFTA by tomorrow, the soft ‘deadline’ imposed by House Speaker Ryan last week. NAFTA deal negotiations remain ongoing. US President committed to getting better trade deal, as according to White House.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said the yield curve does not worry him but he will not ignore its signal and repeated comments from yesterday, “he does not see inflation running away”. Fed’s Bostic (Voter, Dovish) sees strong consumer spending, but uncertainty remains depending on how people and firms will respond to tax cuts. He sees 3 rate hikes in 2018 given the US fiscal stimulus. On geopolitics, he noted the surplus could become a deficit if Iran oil not accessible. Fed's Bullard (Dove, Non-Voter) noted the US is close to neutral rate. He does not see yield curve inversion danger just now stating it has s a nice slope. Global rates are still low, and urged to keep this in mind. He believes it is unlikely that the US economy will outperform current forecasts

*DATA: US Housing Starts Number fell to 1,287K in April missing expectations at 1,310K. Building Permits also fell but the figure came in at 1,352K and was pretty much in line with consensus. The breakdown appears much more encouraging than the headlines, as the drop was mostly attributed to multi-family activity, which surged back in March and saw some adjustment last month. Single-family starts rose by more than anticipated amid the bad weather hitting in March and April. Permits also rose for the period but remain overall flat for the last six months. Analysts at Pantheon noted housing activity has reached a peak for this cycle. US Industrial Production printed at 0.7%, beating slightly the consensus at 0.6% on the back of faster output growth signalling faster economic activity for Q2. Manufacturing Output was in line but encouraging enough to lift 3-year annualised growth to 4.6% in April. Business equipment production also provided support to the figure implying the fall seen in Q1 was only temporary. Analysts at Capital Economics argued that given the current economic conditions, a weaker dollar  and improving relationships between US and China on trade, growth in the industrial sector will remain strong in the incoming months.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.39% at 2722, NDX +0.60% at ,6929 DJI +0.24% at 24700.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.88%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.68%, Energy: +0.33%, Financials: -0.01%, Health Care: +0.48%, Industrials: +0.23, Materials: +0.93%

US Equity futures consolidated around Tuesday’s closing level until US traders got to their desks on Wednesday, content to roam in the range between 2705 and 2720 until afternoon trade, when the ES broke out, but couldn’t manage to hold ground too far above the level after a bout of political headlines from the US (Navarro).

Sector specifics, utilities underperformed given the defensive nature of the sector as it was the only sector in the red at market close following a risk on tone being taken by markets, on the flipside, materials outperformed.

Stocks specifics, Macy’s (M) provided a strong earnings report and also boosted its FY guidance, this also boosted others in the retail sector (KSS, JWN, JCP). Micron (MU) another outperformer in the SPX on Wednesday following a new buy rating at RBC with a price target of $80. Pressuring the SPX was IQVIA Holdings (IQV) following reports during hours from the FDA that quality problems have been related to data provided by IQV, it said they found discrepancy in data which showed more than a 20% drop in the amount of fentanyl sold over five years. 

In M&A news, National Amusements reportedly amended CBS's (CBS) bylaws to require a super majority of CBS board to approve dividends. This comes after CBS sued National Amusements, owned by the Redstones, to dilute their voting power on the board (the move would be from 80% to 17% on CBS's board) in a hope to prevent a merger with Viacom (VIAB). Later, Gasparino reported that CBS is still worried that Redstone will fire the board at tomorrow’s meeting. Elsewhere, Zoetis (ZTS) is to acquire Abaxis (ABAX) for USD 83/shr, which equates to USD 2bln deal. Finally, the European Commission and DOJ hope to complete Monsanto (MON) and Bayer (BAYN GY) review by the end of May.

*CRUDE: WTI futures settle USD 0.18 higher at 71.49/bbl, Brent futures settle USD 0.85 at 79.28/bbl. Brent continues to outperform WTI; today’s divergence can be explained by lingering geopolitical tensions in the Middle East keeping a premium in Brent prices, while US crude output continuing to scale fresh highs weighed on WTI.

* The DOE energy inventory data was at odds with the data reported by the API on Tuesday; crude stocks drew down by 1.4mln (exp draw of 800k), while production continued to rise, this week by around 0.2% to 10.723mln BPD. Cushing stocks, meanwhile showed a small build, in line with the API data and the Genscape Cushing forecast, gasoline stocks drew deeper than expected 3.79mln (exp draw 1.4mln) and distillates drew by 92k, shallower than the expected 2.16mln draw.

* The IEA’s monthly report cut 2018 global oil demand growth forecast to 1.4mln BPD due to rising oil prices. It also said OECD commercial oil inventories declined below the five-year average in March.

* OPEC chief Barkindo said compliance with the OPEC+ output cut deal was running at a record 149% in March. Separately, sources reported that Saudi Arabia believes a brief oil price spike driven by speculators is not a reason for producers to increase output, and said oil prices at $79/bbl are ‘not yet’ too high; the rally towards $80/bbl is driven by Geopolitical tensions, not a supply shortage, according to four OPEC sources. Finally, Iran's oil minister says oil prices at $60-65/bbl are 'logical' - and said that the US wanted higher prices to boost shale production.

* Elsewhere, Iran asked Chinese refiners to maintain imports in the face of US sanctions, and Nigeria’s Trans-Forcados was shut due to a leak, though the news had little impact on prices.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 2 ticks lower at 118-17+.

Treasuries ended the day pretty much unchanged, despite decent volumes and a busy day in the European fixed income complex, where Italian BTPs tumbled amid political uncertainty whilst German bunds acted as a safe haven alternative. Treasury yields were higher by less than 1bps, with the exception of the 10yr yield which was higher by just about 1bps, consolidating yesterday’s gains above the 3% level. Heading towards settlement, 2s10s widened by c.1bps.

*FOREX: EUR: Bottom of the G10 pile as the single currency extended losses through 1.1800 after some barrier resistance and also breached a Fib around 1.1790 on the way to circa 1.1765 and fresh 2018 lows with events in Rome took their toll on the currency. However, a late and broad round of Greenback selling/profit taking after the latest official EM efforts to shore up increasingly depreciating currencies saw the headline pair re-test the big figure.

NZD, AUD, CAD: The non-US Dollars have displayed solid resilience for the most part, even when the DXY carved out a new YTD peak around 93.640, and proffered more when their peer pulled up, with the Kiwi nudging around 0.6900 again, AUDUSD recouping more data-related losses (wages missed overnight) and reclaiming 0.7500. Similarly, the Loonie rebounded further r from recent lows vs the USD, but with the aid of firmer than forecast Canadian factory orders and ongoing hopes that remaining NAFTA ‘Is and Ts’ can be dotted and crossed before Thursday’s soft deadline.

GBP, JPY, CHF: All narrowly mixed and choppy vs the USD as Cable lost grip of 1.3500 again before finding some underlying support (albeit on the aforementioned Buck retreat) and USDJPY meandered between 110.00-40, with the JPY seeing intermittent bids on safe-haven grounds vs offers after a surprise negative Japanese GDP read overnight. Meanwhile, the Franc pivoted around parity, but outperformed the EUR as the cross slipped under 1.1800, possibly prompting some verbal attention from the SNB, but then  rebounded above the figure.

* COMING UP: AUSTRALIAN LABOUR MARKET (Overnight): Australia releases labour market data on Thursday and employment is expected to increase 15K, keeping the unemployment rate at 5.5%. “While it never seemed likely that the exceptionally fast pace of job creation

throughout 2017 would be sustained for long in 2018, we doubt the 6,300 fall in employment in February and lacklustre 4,900 rise in March is a sign of things to come,” said Capital Economics. Looking at labour market indicators, the NAB business conditions index  rose 6 point to +21, its equal highest level since the survey began in 1997 with NAB noting that employment conditions posted strong gains in the month. NAB Group Chief Economist Oster said, “The improvement in the employment index was particularly welcome in the light of the ABS reporting a slowdown in jobs growth in recent months. Historically, the NAB Survey does a good job at looking through short-term cycles in the ABS data and so we think the labour market continues to improve.”

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Eur loses more friends as Italian populists coalesce
content:
EUR

Bottom of the G10 pile as the single currency extended losses through 1.1800 after some barrier resistance and also breached a Fib around 1.1790 on the way to circa 1.1765 and fresh 2018 lows. From a fundamental and flow perspective, events in Rome took their toll on the Eur as the 5-Star and League alliance get closer to a Government coalition deal that looks set to challenge EU and Brussels on various front, while the market base is still long and arguably top heavy. However, a late and broad round of Greenback selling/profit taking after the latest official EM efforts to shore up increasingly depreciating currencies saw the headline pair re-test the big figure.

NZD/AUD/CAD

The non-US Dollars have displayed solid resilience for the most part, even when the DXY carved out a new ytd peak around 93.640, and proffered more when their peer pulled up, with the Kiwi nudging over 0.6900 again, Aud/Usd recouping more data-related losses (wages missed overnight) and reclaiming 0.7500 just in time or perhaps too soon for another big option expiry at the round number. Similarly, the Loonie rebounded further from recent lows vs the Usd, but with the aid of firmer than forecast Canadian factory orders and ongoing hopes that remaining NAFTA ‘Is and Ts’ can be dotted and crossed before Thursday’s soft deadline.

GBP/JPY/CHF

All narrowly mixed and choppy vs the Usd as Cable lost grip of 1.3500 again before finding some underlying support (albeit on the aforementioned Buck retreat) and Usd/Jpy meandered between 110.00-40, with the Jpy seeing intermittent bids on safe-haven grounds vs offers after a surprise negative Japanese GDP read overnight. Meanwhile, the Franc pivoted around parity, but outperformed the Eur as the cross slipped under 1.1800 – possibly prompting some verbal attention from the SNB.

content:

  • Tensions rising on the Korean peninsula as North Korea cancels summit with safe haven currencies bid

  • Looking ahead, highlights include US industrial production, DoE’s, ECB’s Draghi, Praet and Constancio, Fed’s Bullard and Bostic

16th May 2018

Tensions rising on the Korean peninsula as North Korea cancels summit with safe haven currencies bid

FTSE MIB and BTP’s underperforming in the wake of Italian political concerns

Looking ahead, highlights include US industrial production, DoE’s, ECB’s Draghi, Praet and Constancio, Fed’s Bullard and Bostic

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks were mostly negative on spill-over selling from US where the DJIA snapped an 8-day win streak and stocks posted their worst performance in around 3 weeks amid rising yields as markets priced the chances of 4 hikes this year. Furthermore, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) was also dampened by disappointing GDP data from Japan which contracted for the first time in over 2 years and the KOSPI (+0.2%) was kept subdued for most the session by a withering of the geopolitical climate after North Korea cancelled a high-level inter-Korean meeting in resentment to US-South Korea joint military drills and also threatened to reconsider summit with US if they insist on North Korea giving up its nuclear program. Elsewhere, the widespread downbeat tone overshadowed a firm liquidity injection by the PBoC which ensured the Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) conformed to the losses, while ASX 200 (+0.5%) bucked the trend with gains seen across a broad range of sectors and after subdued wage growth data added to the case for the RBA to continue holding off on rate adjustments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat and held near the prior day’s lows as yields attempted to track the upside in US counterparts after the US 10yr briefly approached 3.1% and its highest in around 7 years.

PBoC injected CNY 140bln via 7-day & CNY 120bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 200bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3745 (Prev. 6.3486)

Chinese House Prices (Apr) Y/Y 4.7% (Prev. 4.9%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q1) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP Annualised (Q1) -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 1.6%); 1st contraction in 9 quarters.

CENTRAL BANKS

Riksbank's Skingsley says the SEK has weakened more than they expected in recent months; the timing for rate hikes remains to be seen in her view, but if economy performs as expected, it is natural to start hiking at end of year. (Newswires)

ECB’s Constancio (Dovish) says the slowdown is not “such an unexpected or serious matter”; he adds the ECB has not discussed medium-term future of policy. (Newswires)

Turkish central bank says they are closely monitoring the unhealthy price movements in the market; adding that necessary steps will be taken, also considering the impact of these developments on the outlook for inflation. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea cancelled a high-level meeting with South Korea that was set for today and threatened the cancellation of summit with US amid anger regarding US-South Korea joint military drills. (BBC/Nikkei)

North Korea said it will never engage in economic trade with US in return for dropping nuclear program and that it rejects Libya-style denuclearization for the country, according to state media reports. Furthermore, North Korea added that it will need to reconsider summit with US if it insists on North Korea giving up nuclear program and that US President Trump will remain as failed leader if he chooses to follow along the lines of past US presidents. (KCNA)

South Korea Unification Ministry said the decision by North Korea to cancel high-level meeting for today is regrettable and it urged North Korea to return to talks, while the South Korean Defence Ministry said it will go ahead with drills with US as planned. (Newswires)

Iranian supreme leaders adviser says he doubts talks with Europeans to save nuclear deal would be fruitful. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

BoE Deputy Governor Broadbent said that the UK economy is approaching a 'menopausal' stage after passing peak productivity which risks a once-in-a-century downturn. (Telegraph)

UK Brexit Minister Davis reportedly warned PM May regarding the legality of the customs plan and has reportedly raised the threat of a legal challenge to May in a letter to the PM. (Times)

Italian government deal with the League is to be reached today; according to a 5 Star spokesperson. League says the cancellation of Government debt was never in the official draft of the Government programme, proposed debt bought by ECB not be calculated in EU stability pact evaluations for all countries. (Newswires)

EU CPI Final YY (Apr) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%)

EU CPI Final MM (Apr) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 1.0%)

Italian CPI (EU Norm) Final MM (Apr) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

Italian CPI (EU Norm) Final YY (Apr) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%)

EQUITIES

European bourses trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%) with Italy’s FTSE MIB (-1.6%) underperforming in light of recent political developments including a potential leadership rotation between the League and 5SM, as well as a leaked document which revealed potential policy proposals from the ongoing negotiations which included a EUR 250bln debt write-off (which was then disregarded by the League). Later reports stated that the populist parties proposed debt bought by ECB not be calculated in EU stability pact evaluations for all countries. As a result, Italian banks including Ubi Banca (-1.9%), Bper Banca (-1.0%). Finecobank (-2.3%), UniCredit (-2.6%), Banca Mediolanum (-3.0%) and Banco BPM (-2.7%) are all resting at the bottom of the index.

Elsewhere, material names are benefitting from the firmer base metal prices with the sector outperforming its peers. In terms of individual movers, Micro Focus (+8.8%) is at the top of the FTSE following expectations of better earnings than shown in their guidance. Paddy Power (+5.8%) is also riding high after reports the company is in talks to acquire FanDuel amid the sudden lifting of federal ban on sports betting in the US.

FX

DXY

The DXY has now climbed above 93.500 and tested major chart resistance just above, largely at the expense of extended EUR weakness as the single currency sinks to the bottom of the G10 pile. Eur/Usd held above 1.1800 for a while amidst reported barrier option interest, but big figure psychological and sentimental support have way relatively quickly after that with market contacts also noting sell stops in the Eur cross vs AUD. Note, the Aud was an overnight laggard on softer than forecast Aussie wage data that highlights RBA guidance based on benign pay trends and the impact on inflation overall. Moving back to the DXY it remains firmly underpinned and on course for further upside technically, while the fundamental backdrop also looks supportive as US Treasury yields consolidate close to their highs. However, NK’s decision to postpone its meeting with South Korea and dithering over a summit with the US is a potential counterweight along with ongoing heightened tensions with Iran.

GBP

Also on a weaker footing as Cable retreats below 1.3500 again amidst more negative Brexit headlines.

NZD

Conversely, the Kiwi is the biggest G10 winner by virtue of short covering with Nzd/Usd hovering near the upper end of a 0.6895-50 range.

JPY

Somewhat caught between conflicting impulses in wake of unexpectedly weak Japanese GDP data overnight (1st contraction in 2 years) and safe-haven demand due to the breakdown in NK-SK/US ‘entente cordiale’, with Usd/Jpy above 110.00, but not yet breaking up/out of the 200 DMA resistance zone.

CHF/CAD

Narrowly mixed with the Franc seeing some FTQ in-flows as Usd/Chf pivots around parity and Eur/Chf tests 1.1800, while the Loonie meanders between 1.28540-75 just 24 hours before a potential NAFTA agreement that Canadian PM Trudeau believes is possible.

FIXED INCOME

Not much further deviation in core debt, or upside for German debt even though investors scrambled to get their hands on the latest 10 year Bund cash offering (auction almost 3 times oversubscribed and cover double compared to the previous sale). However, core Eurozone bonds remain firmly underpinned as Italian BTPs succumb to more heavy selling pressure and losses stack up to over 100 ticks, while US Treasuries continue to consolidate and unwind some of Tuesday’s marked bear-steepening.

COMMODITIES

The surprise build in API crude inventories overnight is still weighing on oil, as the fossil fuel is negative for the day, with WTI currently down 0.36% and Brent 0.65% lower. Morgan Stanley (MS) forecasts WTI prices at USD 71/BBL for Q4 2018 and USD 73/BBL for Q1 2019. Safe haven flows and a slightly softer greenback are resulting in Gold trading higher, currently up 0.31% on the day. Chinese Steel and Iron ore futures have undone the gains seen on Tuesday following but still hover close to a 8 week high, with the two metals at USD 577.23/tonne and USD 75.65/tonne respectively.

IEA says global oil demand forecast to 1.4mln BPD vs. prev. 1.5mln BPD in prev. month, "too soon" to predict impact on Iranian crude from sanctions, call on OPEC crude to average 32.35mln BPD for 2018, nearly 600K BPD above April output. (Newswires)

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (May 11) +4.854mln vs. Exp. -0.8mln (Prev. -1.850mln). (Newswires)

Bunds: firm bounce as Italian BTPs plunge
content: Some consolidation in US Treasuries off Tuesday’s lows has given German debt a lift off the Eurex open, but core Eurozone bonds are also benefiting from the demise of Italian BTPs as the political impasse between 5-Star and the League drags on. Bunds were marked up 14 ticks initially, but have extended early gains to 30 ticks at 158.06 vs yesterday’s 157.76 close, while the equivalent Italian benchmark slumped to 136.17 at worst for a near full point drop and the corresponding cash yield hit 2%. Looking ahead, a Government coalition deal could be forthcoming at some stage today, but latest reports suggest some issues remain unresolved, while 10 year German supply may warrant some concession and ECB speakers are also slated, including President Draghi.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks were mostly negative on spill-over selling from US where the DJIA snapped an 8-day win streak and stocks posted their worst performance in around 3 weeks amid rising yields as markets priced the chances of 4 hikes this year. Furthermore, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) was also dampened by disappointing GDP data from Japan which contracted for the first time in over 2 years and the KOSPI (+0.2%) was kept subdued for most the session by a withering of the geopolitical climate after North Korea cancelled a high-level inter-Korean meeting in resentment to US-South Korea joint military drills and also threatened to reconsider summit with US if they insist on North Korea giving up its nuclear program. Elsewhere, the widespread downbeat tone overshadowed a firm liquidity injection by the PBoC which ensured the Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) conformed to the losses, while ASX 200 (+0.5%) bucked the trend with gains seen across a broad range of sectors and after subdued wage growth data added to the case for the RBA to continue holding off on rate adjustments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat and held near the prior day’s lows as yields attempted to track the upside in US counterparts after the US 10yr briefly approached 3.1% and its highest in around 7 years.

FTSE

Paddy Power Betfair (PPB LN) – Co. is in talks to acquire fantasy sports site FanDuel as it looks to capitalise on sudden lifting of federal ban on sports betting across US. Details are unknown and both Co.’s decline to comment. (FT)

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.71% at 2710, NDX -1.08% at 6888, DJI -0.80% at 24700.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.74%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.67%, Energy: -0.16%, Financials: -0.63%, Health Care: -1.47%, Industrials: -0.56%, Materials: -0.53%, Technology: -1.31%, Telecoms: -0.99%, Utilities: -1.16%.

* Overnight, there was a slight downward bias in US equity futures, following a weak close on Wall Street on Monday, and equity weakness in Asia. Selling was accelerated before the cash equity day got underway, after a retail sales report painted an upbeat picture of the consumer sector; traders subsequently raised bets on four hikes this year, sending US Treasury yields above 3%, helping the dollar bounce, but piling pressure on the US equities complex (though financials held up slightly better than other sectors as yields ticked higher). ES slipped before eventually finding support at/above 2700 in afternoon trade.

subject: Italy's 5 Star leader Di Maio and League's Salvini could reportedly take turns as Premier, as according to Corriere Della Sera
DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks were mostly negative on spill-over selling from the US. Sentiment also soured after North Korea cancelled a high-level inter-Korean meeting
content:
Asian stocks were mostly negative on spill-over selling from the US. Sentiment also soured after North Korea cancelled a high-level inter-Korean meeting

UK government is to publish its Brexit White Paper next month. Italy’s 5Sm leader Di Maio said there are still issues to resolve

Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone CPI, US industrial production, DoE’s, ECB’s Draghi, Praet and Constancio, Fed’s Bullard and Bostic

ASIA

Asian stocks were mostly negative on spill-over selling from US where the DJIA snapped an 8-day win streak and stocks posted their worst performance in around 3 weeks amid rising yields as markets priced the chances of 4 hikes this year. Furthermore, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) was also dampened by disappointing GDP data from Japan which contracted for the first time in over 2 years and the KOSPI (+0.2%) was kept subdued for most the session by a withering of the geopolitical climate after North Korea cancelled a high-level inter-Korean meeting in resentment to US-South Korea joint military drills and also threatened to reconsider summit with US if they insist on North Korea giving up its nuclear program. Elsewhere, the widespread downbeat tone overshadowed a firm liquidity injection by the PBoC which ensured the Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) conformed to the losses, while ASX 200 (+0.5%) bucked the trend with gains seen across a broad range of sectors and after subdued wage growth data added to the case for the RBA to continue holding off on rate adjustments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat and held near the prior day’s lows as yields attempted to track the upside in US counterparts after the US 10yr briefly approached 3.1% and its highest in around 7 years.

PBoC injected CNY 140bln via 7-day & CNY 120bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 200bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3745 (Prev. 6.3486)

Chinese House Prices (Apr) Y/Y 4.7% (Prev. 4.9%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q1) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
Japanese GDP Annualised (Q1) -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 1.6%); 1st contraction in 9 quarters.


UK/EU

BoE Deputy Governor Broadbent said that the UK economy is approaching a 'menopausal' stage after passing peak productivity which risks a once-in-a-century downturn. (Telegraph)

UK government is to publish its Brexit White Paper next month, according to sources. The paper will touch on issues such as customs, regulatory divergence and the financial services sector, ahead of the EC meeting next month. (BBC/FT)

UK PM May has been urged to make a quick decision over Britain’s customs relationship with the EU as she promised clarity in time for a key meeting in Brussels next month. (Telegraph)

UK Brexit Minister Davis reportedly warned PM May regarding the legality of the customs plan and has reportedly raised the threat of a legal challenge to May in a letter to the PM. (Times)

Italy’s 5SM leader Di Maio said there are still issues to resolve with League’s Salvini, but later added that a deal may be sealed on Wednesday. (ANSA)

Riksbank’s Skingsley said they are in a nice spot to discuss rates and that SEK slid a bit more than warranted by data, while she also added that path accommodates a rate hike in October. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative said unless the EU stops breaking rules on Airbus subsidies (AIR FP), the US will have to move forward with counter measures on products in the EU, while the French government announced they will respect the international commitments by adopting new measures to comply with the WTO ruling that EU failed to eliminate all subsidies for Airbus. (Newswires)


FX

USD remained firm with the DXY above the 93.00 level after the rise in US yields and with markets leaning more towards the likelihood of 4 hikes this year following an upward revision to Retail Sales. This kept the greenback’s major counterparts subdued, while data was also in focus for Asia-Pac currencies as AUD staggered on softer than expected wages which the RBA have cited on numerous occasions as a factor for the subdued inflation. Elsewhere, the risk averse tone spurred flows into safe-haven JPY, but with price action relatively contained as disappointing GDP data also stoked some calls for future BoJ action.

Australian Wage Price Index (Q1) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%); (Q1) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre mainly due to a firmer greenback which pressured gold heavily in the prior session and although the precious metal has nursed losses overnight, prices still remain as a sub-USD1300/oz level. Elsewhere, copper traded flat after the prior day’s declines as the negative risk tone kept prices subdued, while WTI crude futures were marginally weaker and struggled to hold above USD 71.00 following the USD-induced pullback and surprise build in API crude inventories.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (May 11) +4.854mln vs. Exp. -0.8mln (Prev. -1.850mln). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea cancelled a high-level meeting with South Korea that was set for today and threatened the cancellation of summit with US amid anger regarding US-South Korea joint military drills. (BBC/Nikkei)

North Korea said it will never engage in economic trade with US in return for dropping nuclear program and that it rejects Libya-style denuclearization for the country, according to state media reports. Furthermore, North Korea added that it will need to reconsider summit with US if it insists on North Korea giving up nuclear program and that US President Trump will remain as failed leader if he chooses to follow along the lines of past US presidents. (KCNA)

South Korea Unification Ministry said the decision by North Korea to cancel high-level meeting for today is regrettable and it urged North Korea to return to talks, while the South Korean Defence Ministry said it will go ahead with drills with US as planned. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif stated that after Brussels talks we are on the right track and a lot will depend on what we can do in the next few weeks, while he also stated it is a good start and that political was agreement reached on steps to take. Elsewhere, the Iranian Nuclear Chief stated on state TV the EU should make up for US withdrawal from the deal or else Tehran will enrich uranium “stronger than before”, while the top adviser to Iran’s Supreme leader stated that Tehran will not renegotiate the nuclear deal and will not talk about its missile programme. (Newswires)


US

Treasuries were sold in heavy volume on Tuesday amid upbeat retail sales and a slightly more aggressive tone from Fed’s Kaplan and Fed’s Williams, with heavy corporate supply also adding further downward pressure to the complex. The curve bear-steepened with 2yr yields higher by c.3bps and 30yr yields higher by c.7bps. The10yr yield hit the highest level since May 2011 and took out the April 25th high at 3.033%, 2s30s and 2s10s both widened by c.4bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled down 20+ ticks lower at 118-19+.

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said gradual rate rises and 3 or 4 hikes this year are the right direction for policy but also stated he is conscious rates will remain lower versus historical levels. Williams also commented that he is not concerned if inflation overshoots its target by a few tenths and sees wages rising later this year as economy continues to strengthen, while he added that guidance on ‘accommodative’ policy may need to be tweaked at some point. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said the US could achieve 3% economic growth but hinges on Labour participation and productivity, while he also stated he is not set on 2 or 3 more hikes this year and is watching the yield curve. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said there is an eminently achievable outcome on NAFTA and that “we are very close”. (Newswires)
